image.altText: Christine Gwin travelled to Mumbai for dental work

props.synopsis: An Indian dental clinic which markets cut-price services to Australians has been accused of using fake online reviews and price gouging — leaving one woman in pain after she travelled to the subcontinent for care.

title.children: The Queensland woman in 'constant pain' after travelling to India for cheaper dental work

image.altText: charred helicopter wreckage lifted from hotel roof

props.synopsis: Investigators continue to probe what happened before the allegedly stolen craft crashed.

title.children: Recording devices from helicopter that crashed into Cairns hotel roof sent for analysis as investigation turns to pilot

image.altText: A flag that says CFMEU flying at a construction site.

props.synopsis: A construction industry insider who alleges he was physically struck by a CFMEU member has accused union officials of acting like "the meanest bully you've ever come across."

title.children: 'Enough is enough': Construction insider relates CFMEU 'bully' tactics

image.altText: A young man with a beard poses for a portrait inside, looking into camera with a serious facial expression.

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation has uncovered a probe into nepotism allegations against a senior executive of the Queensland Public Trustee whose son was employed and promoted by the agency.

title.children: 'I was ropeable': Worker missed out on promotion in favour of Public Trustee executive's son

image.altText: A generic stock photo of a teenage school girl leaning against the lockers on her phone.

props.synopsis: A plan for venues, such as pubs and hotels, to verify someone's identity through a QR code will be unveiled today by Bill Shorten. Follow live.

title.children: Plan to allow Aussies to use QR codes to verify ID

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Coalition pushing for inquiry into CFMEU bill
📹 CFMEU legislation a test to for Greens, Coalition, Workplace Relations Minister Murray Watt says
'Extremely disappointing': Greens slam Labor's approach to gambling advertising

image.altText: Albanese walks and looks serious on the lower house floor.

props.synopsis: Laws to restrict gambling advertising are being bargained over inside Labor's caucus, as the prime minister warns a misstep could have "unintended consequences" for Australia.

title.children: Government bargains to win over Labor MPs on laws to ban gambling ads around children's programs and live sport

image.altText: A man and woman stand on a stage

props.synopsis: Once a Democratic stronghold, Wisconsin flipped for Trump in 2016. Now, both Republicans and Democrats are scrambling for votes in America's "dairyland".

title.children: To beat Trump, Harris will likely need this small state. Here's how she and Walz are faring in Wisconsin

image.altText: man in orange shirt and floppy hat smiling in front of tractor

props.synopsis: Sam Hughes had a gap year idea that turned into an epic adventure. He spent three years travelling on a tractor around the country and raised $260,000 for three rural charities.

title.children: Why this 21yo spent three years on a tractor trek around Australia

image.altText: Crowd of people on the streets of Sydney

props.synopsis: Whatever way you try to split it, the generational divide between millennials and baby boomers is growing — and it's our Australian obsession with owning property that is widening the gap, and interest rates that are keeping it that way.

title.children: The great wealth shuffle. Why millennials are missing out

image.altText: a crowd watches a group play a card game

props.synopsis: A Chinese state-backed newspaper urges people to stop playing a popular card game, arguing it is addictive and distracting people from their work.

title.children: Chinese media denounce card game enjoyed by Communist Party officials

image.altText: Elon Musk

props.synopsis: The site showed that the page was "not available" shortly after the scheduled start for some users.

title.children: Elon Musk claims 'massive DDOS attack' on X during Donald Trump interview

image.altText: A hand holding a microphone. Foam on top of the microphone has '7 News' on it.

props.synopsis: Four Corners has spoken to more than 200 people to investigate allegations of Channel Seven's toxic culture, uncovering allegations of bullying, sexism, and exploitation.

title.children: 'This was a tool, a tactic': When Channel 7 staff complained, management had HR turn on them

image.altText: A man in a checquered shirt holds a heavy hose as another man sprays a large fire

props.synopsis: Greece is on fire watch as high temperatures and dangerous weather conditions fan a dangerous wildfire near the capital.

title.children: Wildfire with flames as high as 25 metres rages near Athens

image.altText: Sinead Diver pictured in action at the Tokyo Olympics

props.synopsis: Sinéad Diver described the lead-up to the marathon at the Paris Olympics as "one of the most challenging times of my life" and believes the criticism she's faced contributed to her body breaking down during the race.

title.children: Sinéad Diver claims 'vitriol online' contributed to debilitating cramps that ended her OIympic marathon after just 1.2km

image.altText: A man sits at a colourful poker machine. He is silhouetted by its light. Two other pokies sit next to it.

props.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns banned full-day retail trade on the national day of remembrance, with the exemption of "essential" service providers including hotels and clubs.

title.children: Alex Greenwich calls for poker machines to be 'given a rest' in Anzac Day ban proposal

image.altText: A character stands next to a video game depiction of red and yellow post boxes

props.synopsis: Will Australia's next iconic artwork be a game? As the industry matures, a growing suite of Aussie game developers is helping players explore never-before-seen regions and communities … and make some uncomfortable choices.

title.children: How childhood nostalgia for the Sunshine Coast inspired this game developer to set her next game there

image.altText: A person walks down a new suburban street as the sun sets.

props.synopsis: Melbourne's population continues to grow, but there are growing calls for services such as public transport to be expanded to match the boom.

title.children: Melbourne is growing fast, but on the fringes, public transport isn't

image.altText: An aerial photo of an aircraft carrier with a host of fighter jets parked on board sails in the open sea

props.synopsis: The US has ordered a guided missile submarine to the Middle East and is instructing the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier strike group to accelerate its deployment to the region, amid fears Iran or its proxies may launch a strike against Israel as soon as this week.

title.children: US boosts military presence in Middle East, warns an Iran-backed attack on Israel could come this week

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo, known as Lawyer X, wearing a leopard print top stares out a window

props.synopsis: The Victorian government has revealed it plans to introduce laws preventing anyone seeking to sue Victoria Police in relation to the disastrous Lawyer X affair — in which Ms Gobbo provided information to police about her gangland clients.

title.children: Lawyers for Nicola Gobbo blindsided by Victorian government bid to block police lawsuit

image.altText: A glum family sits outside tents with two children blowing bubbles

props.synopsis: Kyiv now controls 1,000 square kilometres of Russian land, Ukraine's top commander said, as they continue its largest cross-border attack in almost two-and-a-half years of full-scale war.

title.children: Putin says 'the enemy will certainly receive a worthy response' as Ukraine says it controls 1,000 square km of Russian land

image.altText: A marle statue of three headless female figures, standing nude, side by side, with arms on one another.

props.synopsis: From the influence of the devil to overzealous restorers, there are numerous strange reasons and theories behind the conspicuous lack of pubic hair on women depicted in Western art.

title.children: The nude female body has been depicted in art countless times. But where is all the pubic hair?

image.altText: Close up of a hand holding glass under a streaming tap, above a kitchen sink. The glass is full of clear water.

props.synopsis: In April the American environmental protection agency announced there is no safe level of so-called "forever chemicals" in drinking water and set enforceable limits across the country. Australian experts are asking why we're not doing the same.

title.children: Harmful PFAS chemicals are in everyday products, so how can we minimise their risk?

image.altText: A woman wearing a hijab and long dress stands next to a window in a corridor with her hand on the window sill

props.synopsis: People from southern Lebanon have had to flee the daily air strikes on their villages, and for months have stayed in derelict hotels-turned-shelters.

title.children: Displaced Lebanese beg to go home as country braces for worse fighting

image.altText: Police tape at a crime scene

props.synopsis: The Victorian government is promising tougher bail accountability for young people accused of serious crimes but is backing out of a pledge to raise the age of criminal responsibility to 14.

title.children: Victorian government backs away from pledge to raise the age of criminal responsibility to 14

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has opened flat today after a mixed day on US and global markets. Rising geopolitical tensions are pushing energy prices higher. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Australian share market opens flat

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Consumers feeling (slightly) less gloomy about interest rates, according to Westpac survey
Energy and real estate stocks up, health and education down

image.altText: Graham Thorpe pictured while coaching for England

props.synopsis: The family of recently-deceased English cricket great Graham Thorpe has revealed he took his own life after a lengthy battle with depression and anxiety despite trying "many, many treatments".

title.children: 'Can affect anyone': Graham Thorpe's wife reveals late English cricket great suffered from depression and anxiety

image.altText: A photo of a man in a lab.

props.synopsis: More than two dozen lab tests have been unable to diagnose long COVID, according to new research which suggests there may be no reliable way to diagnose the condition.

title.children: There is no single test to diagnose long COVID patients, international researchers say

image.altText: Raygun performs at the Paris Olympics

props.synopsis: A friend and fellow breaker has leapt to Rachael "Raygun" Gunn's defence after her controversial performance in Paris, but an African American man living in Australia says she appeared to be mocking black culture.

title.children: How did Raygun qualify for the Olympics? Is she really the best Australia has to offer?

image.altText: A lit up taxi sign next to a hand holding phone with Uber sign

props.synopsis: While the taxi industry has taken steps to modernise — including a burgeoning partnership with its main competitors — there are signs it's still grappling to meet the needs of the market.

title.children: 12 years after Uber's arrival, there are signs the taxi industry is still struggling to stay competitive

image.altText: Kyle Flanagan and Stephen Crichton

props.synopsis: Kyle Flanagan's old teammate believes "you have a choice not to bite someone" as the Dragons star gets set to front the judiciary to defend himself amid claims he bit Bulldogs skipper Stephen Crichton.

title.children: 'Someone doesn't bite themselves': Ex-teammate's damning assessment on Kyle Flanagan allegations ahead of judiciary hearing

image.altText: A male splendid fairywren stands in dappled light with a sunbeam lighting its head.

props.synopsis: They may seem like just a beautiful blue bird, but under the surface the social dynamics of the splendid fairy-wren is anything but simple.

title.children: 'Like watching a soap opera': The splendid social life of Australia’s bluest bird
